name: Luiz
comment info:
Catchy Headline: On the Brink: Could Earth be Facing a Fiery Future?
1. The persistent rise in global surface air temperatures reveals a troubling reality. Despite collective efforts across the globe to combat climate change, there has been little significant progress. Years of initiatives and awareness have yielded limited success, highlighting the urgency for a new approach.

2. It’s increasingly evident that more radical policy adjustments and agreements are imperative. Propelling the production of electric vehicles over conventional fuel-based cars is a prime example of a shift that could markedly decrease pollution levels. Furthermore, harnessing renewable energy sources such as solar and biomass is a crucial step towards mitigating further environmental degradation.

3. With the arrival of summer, the reliance on air conditioning becomes almost indispensable, fuelling a continuous cycle of energy use. Alarmingly, a growing trend amongst teenagers is a preference for indoor activities, which inadvertently promotes an unhealthy lifestyle. The need for transformative actions is more pressing than ever to avert the escalating climate crisis.

name: Denise G
comment info:
(Sayles,Period 8)

1.After brief overview of the graph it can noted that the global mean surface air temperature exhibited a gradual upward trend from 1979 to 2022, culminating in a noteworthy inflection point on July 17, 2023, when it attained its zenith. Specifically, the global temperature remained consistently below 62 degrees Fahrenheit throughout the period spanning from 1979 to 2022.  This transition is discernible in the graphical representation, where the daily global temperature between 1979 and 2022 demonstrated a conspicuous convergence towards the pinnacle of 64 degrees Fahrenheit, presaging the subsequent ascent in 2023.
2. Considering the subtle shifts evident in the graph, it prompts contemplation of whether a discernible correlation exists between this temperature trend and overarching environmental phenomena, notably climate change.
3. This information holds relevance for our community by fostering awareness regarding the evolving global temperature dynamics. An instance of the climate's profound impact on New Jersey residents occurred earlier this year when Canadian wildfires casted their influence. The incident unfolded as smoke and pollutants were transported by prevailing wind patterns, subsequently impacting our air quality, and endangering all residents, particularly exacerbating health concerns among those grappling with respiratory ailments.
4. Global Temperature Trends: Gradual Rise Leads to Record-Breaking High in 2023

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Denise G --

I love your language.  Rarely do we read such expression for a simple graph.
Think about, though -- 
Do we know which line is which year?  Do we know that temperatures exhibited a gradual upward trend from 1979 to 2022?  
Is July 17 an "inflection point"?
Is July 17, 2023 a “zenith”?  
Careful on the use of the word "correlation."  In statistics, it is used when comparing two quantitative variables – like temperature and amount of carbon emissions.  Here, we would probably look for an "association," unless we are defining climate change in terms of a quantitative variable.

comment info:
This graph aims to show the spike in air temperature. This spike happened during this recent summer. However, there had been a slight increase in temp since around April 14th. In the months leading up to summer, there had also been about a .3-degree increase compared to last year. Then in summer, the average temp jumped to a whole degree over 2022 and a record high since 1979.
             "Why did this happen?" I wonder. One popular and common answer these days is global warming. With the increase in global warming, it'd make sense to see an increase in temperature. However, many also believe this may have something to do with the Wildfire in Canada.
            The Canadian wildfire, left much of New York in smoke. Smoke that drifted as far down the coast as North Carolina. The date of the fire starting coincides very well with the prominent spike. And if its causing that much smoke, is it not plausible that it could cause the bump in air temperatures? 
        The only problem with this theory is that, their have been multiple wildfires and forest fires in the past and yet they dont seem to have shown any spikes. So why is this specific on so significant? It might be due to its timing being in the middle of summer. Whatever the reason may be, its very interesting that it happened. That's why Id make the headline of this graph. "Who knew such a cool event... Could be so hot!"

name: Cecilia C. Block 1
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
This graph is truly frightening. It shows us the dire way in which global temperature has been changing, and 2023 is disturbingly drastic. The temperature in each year follows a similar path: a relatively low, cool temperature to start off the year,  a slow ascendance up into the hot, summer months, and an equally slow descendance down again, wrapping up the year and tying it into a neat little bow. 2023 starts off the year fairly normal. It begins the year with a temperature of around 56 degrees, same as the others. Then June hits, and temperatures soar to 62.5, the highest temperature recorded since before 1979, according to this graph. 

What comes next? It is impossible for me to believe that human activity had no impact on this sudden surge in heat, what else could cause such a catastrophic change in only a year? We have been warned: told again and again about the effects of our actions, our insistence to continue drilling, to continue polluting the place we call home, and while we pretend to care, we do nothing. It is as if we are slowly falling into an apocalypse.  How are we going to recover? Are we going to adjust, find some miraculous way to save ourselves and live out the rest of our existence surviving upon the corpse of a once vivid, breathing planet, now an ashen ghost of a life? Or will we die a slow death, blissfully unaware of our dwindling state of life until it is all too late? As much as we try to ignore it all, someday it is sure to catch up to us.

If the earth is getting hotter, causing ice caps to melt which only causes sea levels to rise, when will sinking countries, like Malaysia, be fully submerged?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Alex Wang --

You asked the terrific question that was asked by the first response to this graph:  If this data was from sources both in the Northern and Southern Hemisphere, and since the Southern Hemisphere has the opposite seasons of the Northern Hemisphere, why is the graph so steep?

I wrote to Sue of Palo Alto:

I checked back with the Climate Reanalyzer, Climate Change Institute at the University of Maine, and the graph does accurately show the temperatures for the entire world.  

So, what could be happening?  If this is correct, the temperatures in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres could not be reflections of each other.  Something else is going on.  What could that be?

If you return on Friday, you can read in the Reveal, which is published below this Release, why this graph is not flat with the response from the Climate Reanalyzer.  Also, we will share the free link to the article that included this graph.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info:
@Sue - I wanted to understand more about how the data was gathered/weighted, so went to the source and discovered additional views of the surface temperature broken down by hemisphere. The Northern Hemisphere temperature range is more extreme than the Southern -- historically between roughly 9 and 21 degrees C (48 to 70 F), whereas the Southern Hemisphere ranges from 11 to 17 degrees C (52 to  63 F). Am I correct in assuming this is due to the fact that two-thirds of the land mass on earth is in the Northern Hemisphere? (i.e., the larger ocean area working as more of a temperature "buffer"?) 

Regardless of the underlying reason, the differences in range between the hemispheres would explain why the graph isn't as flat as one would expect.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Sue This is a valid question; the title of the graph suggests that it is the entire world, so why isn't it flatter? I wonder if they also included temperatures in Antarctica, because that would certainly balance out hotter places.
